There are many circumstances in which you may want to or even have to move the value of your retirement benefits from one arrangement to another;

1. **Termination** of employment when you move jobs,
2. The company pension scheme has been **wound up**,
3. May want to move to a more **appropriate** arrangement, for example if you have moved tax jurisdiction,
4. **Consolidate** a number of funds,
5. Look for better investment **options** or reduced charges.

There are **different rules relating to the potential transferability of retirement benefits** between;

1. Occupational Pension Schemes (company pensions)
2. Personal Pensions
3. PRSAs (Personal Retirement Savings Account)
4. PRB/BOB (Personal Retirement Bond or Buy-out Bond)
5. Overseas Transfers. Pensions from other tax jurisdictions eg UK

For overseas transfers pensions must be transferred into a **Qualifying Recognised Overseas Pension Scheme (QROPS)**. 

There are specific rules around these transfers, for example, If the transfer value is greater than Â£30,000 and coming from a Defined Benefit Scheme, then it is a UK mandatory requirement that the member receive independent financial advice from an advisor in the UK that is authorised by the UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to provide a transfer value analysis.

Your financial adviser will help advise you what transfers are qualified or restricted for your pension arrangements.

**If you have an overseas pension that you are considering transferring to Ireland find out today what are your options.**
